items.title: Infrastructure Laundering: Blending in with the Cloud
items.author: BrianKrebs
items.content:
Image: Shutterstock, ArtHead.

In an effort to blend in and make their malicious traffic tougher to block, hosting firms catering to cybercriminals in China and Russia increasingly are funneling their operations through major U.S. cloud providers. Research published this week on one such outfit ‚Äî a sprawling network tied to Chinese organized crime gangs and aptly named ‚Äú‚Äù ‚Äî highlights a persistent whac-a-mole problem facing cloud services.

In October 2024, the security firm published a lengthy analysis of how and were providing services to Funnull, a two-year-old Chinese content delivery network that hosts a wide variety of fake trading apps, pig butchering scams, gambling websites, and retail phishing pages.

Funnull made headlines last summer after it acquired the domain name , previously the home of a widely-used open source code library that allowed older browsers to handle advanced functions that weren‚Äôt natively supported. There were still tens of thousands of legitimate domains linking to the Polyfill domain at the time of its acquisition, and Funnull soon after conducted a supply-chain attack that redirected visitors to malicious sites.

Silent Push‚Äôs October 2024 report found a vast number of domains hosted via Funnull promoting gambling sites that bear the logo of the , a Chinese entity named in a 2024 UN report (PDF) for laundering millions of dollars for the North Korean Lazarus Group.

It is likely the gambling sites coming through Funnull are abusing top casino brands as part of their money laundering schemes. In reporting on Silent Push‚Äôs October report, obtained a comment from Bwin, one of the casinos being advertised en masse through Funnull, and Bwin said those websites did not belong to them.

Gambling is illegal in China except in Macau, a special administrative region of China. Silent Push researchers say Funnull may be helping online gamblers in China evade the Communist party‚Äôs ‚ÄúGreat Firewall,‚Äù which blocks access to gambling destinations.

Silent Push‚Äôs said that upon revisiting Funnull‚Äôs infrastructure again this month, they found dozens of the same Amazon and Microsoft cloud Internet addresses still forwarding Funnull traffic through a dizzying chain of auto-generated domain names before redirecting malicious or phishous websites.

Edwards said Funnull is a textbook example of an increasing trend Silent Push calls ‚Äúinfrastructure laundering,‚Äù wherein crooks selling cybercrime services will relay some or all of their malicious traffic through U.S. cloud providers.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs crucial for global hosting companies based in the West to wake up to the fact that extremely low quality and suspicious web hosts based out of China are deliberately renting IP space from multiple companies and then mapping those IPs to their criminal client websites,‚Äù Edwards told KrebsOnSecurity. ‚ÄúWe need these major hosts to create internal policies so that if they are renting IP space to one entity, who further rents it to host numerous criminal websites, all of those IPs should be reclaimed and the CDN who purchased them should be banned from future IP rentals or purchases.‚Äù

A Suncity gambling site promoted via Funnull. The sites feature a prompt for a Tether/USDT deposit program.

Reached for comment, Amazon referred this reporter to a statement Silent Push included in a report released today. Amazon said AWS was already aware of the Funnull addresses tracked by Silent Push, and that it had suspended all known accounts linked to the activity.

Amazon said that contrary to implications in the Silent Push report, it has every reason to aggressively police its network against this activity, noting the accounts tied to Funnull used ‚Äúfraudulent methods to temporarily acquire infrastructure, for which it never pays. Thus, AWS incurs damages as a result of the abusive activity.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen AWS‚Äôs automated or manual systems detect potential abuse, or when we receive reports of potential abuse, we act quickly to investigate and take action to stop any prohibited activity,‚Äù Amazon‚Äôs statement continues. ‚ÄúIn the event anyone suspects that AWS resources are being used for abusive activity, we encourage them to report it to AWS Trust & Safety using the report abuse form. In this case, the authors of the report never notified AWS of the findings of their research via our easy-to-find security and abuse reporting channels. Instead, AWS first learned of their research from a journalist to whom the researchers had provided a draft.‚Äù

Microsoft likewise said it takes such abuse seriously, and encouraged others to report suspicious activity found on its network.

‚ÄúWe are committed to protecting our customers against this kind of activity and actively enforce acceptable use policies when violations are detected,‚Äù Microsoft said in a written statement. ‚ÄúWe encourage reporting suspicious activity to Microsoft so we can investigate and take appropriate actions.‚Äù

is threat intelligence lead at . Hummel said it used to be that ‚Äúnoisy‚Äù and frequently disruptive malicious traffic ‚Äî such as automated application layer attacks, and ‚Äúbrute force‚Äù efforts to crack passwords or find vulnerabilities in websites ‚Äî came mostly from botnets, or large collections of hacked devices.

But he said the vast majority of the infrastructure used to funnel this type of traffic is now proxied through major cloud providers, which can make it difficult for organizations to block at the network level.

‚ÄúFrom a defenders point of view, you can‚Äôt wholesale block cloud providers, because a single IP can host thousands or tens of thousands of domains,‚Äù Hummel said.

In May 2024, KrebsOnSecurity published a deep dive on Stark Industries Solutions, an ISP that materialized at the start of Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine and has been used as a global proxy network that conceals the true source of cyberattacks and disinformation campaigns against enemies of Russia. Experts said much of the malicious traffic  traversing Stark‚Äôs network (e.g. vulnerability scanning and password brute force attacks) was being bounced through U.S.-based cloud providers.

Stark‚Äôs network has been a favorite of the Russian hacktivist group called , which frequently launches huge distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks against a variety of targets seen as opposed to Moscow. Hummel said NoName‚Äôs history suggests they are adept at cycling through new cloud provider accounts, making anti-abuse efforts into a game of whac-a-mole.

‚ÄúIt almost doesn‚Äôt matter if the cloud provider is on point and takes it down because the bad guys will just spin up a new one,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEven if they‚Äôre only able to use it for an hour, they‚Äôve already done their damage. It‚Äôs a really difficult problem.‚Äù

Edwards said Amazon declined to specify whether the banned Funnull users were operating using compromised accounts or stolen payment card data, or something else.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm surprised they wanted to lean into ‚ÄòWe‚Äôve caught this 1,200+ times and have taken these down!‚Äô and yet didn‚Äôt connect that each of those IPs was mapped to [the same] Chinese CDN,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just thankful Amazon confirmed that account mules are being used for this and it isn‚Äôt some front-door relationship. We haven‚Äôt heard the same thing from Microsoft but it‚Äôs very likely that the same thing is happening.‚Äù

Funnull wasn‚Äôt always a bulletproof hosting network for scam sites. Prior to 2022, the network was known as , based in the Philippines. One of Anjie‚Äôs properties was a website called . Loading that domain reveals a pop-up message by the original Anjie CDN owner, who said their operations had been seized by an entity known as and , the parent company of Funnull.

A machine-translated message from the former owner of Anjie CDN, a Chinese content delivery network that is now Funnull.

‚ÄúAfter I got into trouble, the company was managed by my family,‚Äù the message explains. ‚ÄúBecause my family was isolated and helpless, they were persuaded by villains to sell the company. Recently, many companies have contacted my family and threatened them, believing that Fangneng CDN used penetration and mirroring technology through customer domain names to steal member information and financial transactions, and stole customer programs by renting and selling servers. This matter has nothing to do with me and my family. Please contact Fangneng CDN to resolve it.‚Äù

In January 2024, the U.S. Department of Commerce issued a proposed rule that would require cloud providers to create a ‚ÄúCustomer Identification Program‚Äù that includes procedures to collect data sufficient to determine whether each potential customer is a foreign or U.S. person.

According to the law firm , the Commerce rule also would require ‚Äúinfrastructure as a service‚Äù (IaaS) providers to report knowledge of any transactions with foreign persons that might allow the foreign entity to train a large AI model with potential capabilities that could be used in malicious cyber-enabled activity.

‚ÄúThe proposed rulemaking has garnered global attention, as its cross-border data collection requirements are unprecedented in the cloud computing space,‚Äù Crowell wrote. ‚ÄúTo the extent the U.S. alone imposes these requirements, there is concern that U.S. IaaS providers could face a competitive disadvantage, as U.S. allies have not yet announced similar foreign customer identification requirements.‚Äù

It remains unclear if the new White House administration will push forward with the requirements. The Commerce action was mandated as part of an executive order President Trump issued a day before leaving office in January 2021.
